quote-text: [Ricardo Reis] spoke Marcenda’s name in a low voice, and observed himself carefully, like a chemist who has mixed an acid with a base and is shaking the test tube. There is not much to see without the help of one’s imagination, the salt produced was as expected, for so many thousands of years have we been mixing sentiments, acids and bases, men and women. He recalled the youthful infatuation with which he had first looked upon her, then persuaded himself that he had been moved by pity, compassion for that embittering infirmity, the lump hand, the pale, sad face.  Then followed a long dialogue before the mirror, the tree of knowledge of good and evil, no knowledge is needed, it is enough to look.
quote-source: JosÃ© Saramago, The Year of the Death of Ricardo Reis, translated from the Portuguese by Giovanni Pontiero. Pages 148 in the 1999 Harvill Press paperback edition.
